Input.threadtitle: My week 4 solution and question about Peter's solution
Input.posts:
Hi !! Could somebody check my solution ? I did some chords substitutions that i don't know if they are ok.  (By the way sorry for the mess. I'm not good with MuseScore yet). I also have some question about Peter's solution.  1-. How do we write a 1st inversion of a iiº chord ? And the second? I don't understand de iiº65 in the solution. 2-. In the third bar the Eb is a NCT the half of his value as we change chord during the duration of Eb. Is there some name for that? Could we consider that as a suspension? Thank you. Rubén.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Ruben 1. 1st inversion of a iiº chord is simply iiº6, and second would be iiº6/4. In the solution, iiº6/5 refers to the iiº7 chord in first inversion. Maybe it's not obvious to you, but the C is in the melody line in the oboe (sustained over from beat 1), making up the notes for iiº6/5 (F-Ab-C-D).  2. Yes, this NCT is a suspension. Specifically, a 6-5 suspension.  Regarding your chord substitutions, you have done a iiº6/5 substitution of the iv chord in bar4 like in the solution. In bar 7, you have used the viio7 as the dominant substitution. The inversion however is viio6/5. I would much prefer that you stick with D in the bass, and voice the right hand as G#-B-F. That will give us the full voicing of the viio6/5 chord in both beats.  Other things that I have noticed is that you don't have a very smooth piano right hand chord voicing. For example, there are leaps in the chords in bars 3-4, bars 10-11, and 12-13. Maybe you'd want to rectify this to make the accompaniment flow more smoothly. Also, your parallel period is just basically a repetition of the first phrase only with the addition of the VI chord to the second phrase, which is a bit awkward. Try to change more of the melody/chord progressions so that you can lead up to the V-VI cadence in a more 'natural' manner. Also, the leap of a 9th in the melody in bar 5 (similarly, bars 10 and 14) is too wide and un-stylistic. It makes more sense if the Ab resolves stepwise down to the G instead.   Hope it helps!

Input.posts:
Hi !! Could somebody check my solution ? I did some chords substitutions that i don't know if they are ok.  (By the way sorry for the mess. I'm not good with MuseScore yet). I also have some question about Peter's solution.  1-. How do we write a 1st inversion of a iiº chord ? And the second? I don't understand de iiº65 in the solution. 2-. In the third bar the Eb is a NCT the half of his value as we change chord during the duration of Eb. Is there some name for that? Could we consider that as a suspension? Thank you. Rubén.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Ruben 1. 1st inversion of a iiº chord is simply iiº6, and second would be iiº6/4. In the solution, iiº6/5 refers to the iiº7 chord in first inversion. Maybe it's not obvious to you, but the C is in the melody line in the oboe (sustained over from beat 1), making up the notes for iiº6/5 (F-Ab-C-D).  2. Yes, this NCT is a suspension. Specifically, a 6-5 suspension.  Regarding your chord substitutions, you have done a iiº6/5 substitution of the iv chord in bar4 like in the solution. In bar 7, you have used the viio7 as the dominant substitution. The inversion however is viio6/5. I would much prefer that you stick with D in the bass, and voice the right hand as G#-B-F. That will give us the full voicing of the viio6/5 chord in both beats.  Other things that I have noticed is that you don't have a very smooth piano right hand chord voicing. For example, there are leaps in the chords in bars 3-4, bars 10-11, and 12-13. Maybe you'd want to rectify this to make the accompaniment flow more smoothly. Also, your parallel period is just basically a repetition of the first phrase only with the addition of the VI chord to the second phrase, which is a bit awkward. Try to change more of the melody/chord progressions so that you can lead up to the V-VI cadence in a more 'natural' manner. Also, the leap of a 9th in the melody in bar 5 (similarly, bars 10 and 14) is too wide and un-stylistic. It makes more sense if the Ab resolves stepwise down to the G instead.   Hope it helps!

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi there Enrico Good work. Here are my comments for you.  1. Yes it is acceptable, if this is what you prefer.  2. The F# in bar 2 is a non-chord tone. It is specifically called a chromatic neighbor tone, where the neighbour tone (F) is sharpened to give an interesting sound to the music. You can generally sharpen and flatten neighbour tones to give off this effect, but make sure that it is a semitone up or below the chord tone (hence the name chromatic neighbour tone). So, knowing this you can do the same with the F in your second bar (similarly in bar 7). A few other comments regarding your work: 3. In bar 3, you have used the chord VII6 in between i chords. This is not very good, and not stylistic either. We don't actually see the VII chord used in this manner in music of the Classical era. A passing 6-4 (V6/4) is rather used between chords i6 and i. 4. You have a deceptive cadence at bar 10 - good. You might consider sustaining the melody at this bar (pausing to make the deceptive cadence more prominent), rather than moving on with the melody.  5. You have the right idea of P.A.C. at the end, but you have forgotten the third in the i chord. It is important to have the third as it is the note which gives us the identity and quality of the chord. Hope it helps!
